definition:
A subset $F$ of a topological space $X$ is [*reducible*]{} if it can be
written as a union $F = F_1 \cup F_2$ of two closed proper subsets
$F_1$, $F_2$ of $F$ (closed in the subspace topology). That is, $F$ is
reducible if it can be written as a union
$F = (G_1\cap F)\cup(G_2\cap F)$ where $G_1$,$G_2$ are closed subsets of
$X$, neither of which contains $F$.

A subset of a topological space is [*irreducible*]{} (or
*hyperconnected*) if it is not reducible.

As an example, consider $\{ (x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2 : xy = 0 \}$ with the
subspace topology from $\mathbb{R}^2$. This space is a union of two
lines $\{ (x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2 : x = 0 \}$ and
$\{ (x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2 : y = 0 \}$, which are proper closed subsets.
So this space is reducible, and thus not irreducible.
